course_title: Being Human: Cultural Diversity and Experience

learning_outcomes.description: A well-founded understanding of anthropology, in particular how it relates to and differs from other disciplines and contributes to understanding the diversity of human worlds.
The ability to apply ethically informed and critical analysis in responses to contemporary problems and in the interests of fairness, equality and inclusivity.
The skills to collect, organise and analyse sociocultural research including that drawing from the anthropological literature and that resulting from original research.
Proficiency and fluency in oral and written communication that conveys knowledge, ideas and complex questions about social relationships and human culture.

assessments.task_description:
Participation is a key aspect of assessment in this course and involves attending and contributing to discussion in the face to face tutorials as well as completing tasks associated with the self-paced online workshops.

1.ONLINE METHODS WORKSHOPS = 10%

There are five (5) ONLINE WORKSHOPS, EACH comprised of a short instructional video explaining a key skill for ethnographers and instructions for an associated student activity. Students watch the instructional videos, do self-paced activities and upload their results online [using Padlet].

Each workshop contributes to skills and successful completion of the final essay (assessment 3). Students can complete the responses at any time up to the end of Week 12, but are encouraged to undertake these in the weeks indicated, as noted in the weekly learning activities schedule.

To gain full participation marks, students must

a. Follow the instructions in the instructional video and in any written instructions on Blackboard Ultra, and

b. Upload and share five (5) responses on the Padlet. Workshop participation total  =10%

2.FACE-TO-FACE PARTICIPATION IN 8 TUTORIALS = 10%

There are EIGHT face to face TUTORIALS assessed. Students are expected to attend and contribute actively to topic discussions by referring to reading, lecture and topic materials of relevance. Tutorial participation = 10%

Feedback on this assessment (grade out of 5) will be provided to students via the Blackboard Ultra site at the end of week 5 (after 4 tutorials).

Marking criteria and/or marking rubrics are available in the ‘Assessment’ folder in Blackboard Ultra for this course.

assessments.assessment_title: Doing Anthropology - Final Essay and Coded Notes
assessments.task_description:
This assessment entails combining ethnographic interview data collection (one interview) and research in the anthropological literature to write an essay. Students have a choice of two topics (see below), but will generate their own essay title and content based on original research (interview and data analysis) matched with research in the academic literature (anthropology articles, books, etc.).

Topic 1: Economics Interview a close friend or relative about their ideas related to economics; trade, money, value, labour, or some other aspect of economic life. In the essay you will consider a broader question about socio-economic life, using the results of this interview. How does the data from the interview reflect/contrast with broader sociocultural and/or historical conditions or realities? Re-consider the lecture and relevant reading material from the course. Your essay must include a kinship diagram in which you 'map' any connections between members of the family to which your interviewee refers (for example, if you were interested in the lines of inheritance of material wealth, the values in a family business, or the labour choices among family members). Your essay must also reference at least 3 academic anthropological sources such as journal articles, book chapters, or books. The essay must conclude with a question or tentative finding about the economic matters you investigated. 

Topic 2: Politics Interview a close friend or relative about political (or apolitical!) views, political party membership, activism, experience of working in bureaucracy or some other aspect of political life. In the essay you will tell a story with the results of this interview. How does the data from the interview reflect/contrast with broader sociocultural and/or historical conditions or realities? Your essay must include a kinship diagram in which you 'map' the connections between any members of the family to which your interviewee refers (for example, if you were interested in political party membership, traditions of activism among family members, or opposing views within a family group). Your essay must also reference at least 3 academic anthropological sources such as journal articles, book chapters, or books. The essay must conclude with a question or tentative finding about the political matters you investigated. 

Assessment

  1. 'Coded'/analysed notes of own data (interview): 10% (max two pages) The sample of Coded notes must be submitted at the same time as the essay and in the same document. Students receive training on how to code their notes (see online workshop 5) and guidance in tutorials. Coded notes MUST include references to at least 3 relevant (anthropological) pieces of literature . Coded notes will be submitted via TurnitIn at the same time as the essay and in the same document.
  2. Essay (max 1500 words): 35% All essays must include a title, your name, student number, page numbers, and be in Times New Roman 12 pt font. Essays must be properly referenced in APA (7) style, with at least 3 anthropology sources.

Follow these instructions:

Step 1: Consider the reading material from the course on 'Politics' (week 9) or 'Economics' (week 6). Make a decision to investigate EITHER economics or politics (see below). Step 2: Write some interview questions and undertake a short (roughly 30-60 min) interview with a friend or family member on the topic. Step 3: Collate the notes you took during the interview or make notes using the audio recording and/or transcript of your interview. Step 4: analyse your notes, using the process of 'coding' (see online workshop 5). Then, using the keywords that arise ('codes') in the process of this coding, Step 5: engage in research in the anthropological literature to find anthropological papers which help you 'make sense' of and discuss the themes. The final essay you write will combine your data (from the interview) and the anthropological literature from the course outline and your research to help you make sense of what your interviewee tells you in relation to either economics or politics. The essay will include an appendix that provides a sample (no more than 2 pages) of your analysed data ('Coded notes'). 

The Final Essay assessment (+ coded notes) must be submitted by Friday, Week 13 at 2 p.m.

Marking criteria and/or marking rubrics are available in the ‘Assessment’ folder in Blackboard Ultra for this course.

This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is not encouraged for this task. If the student uses these tools, a statement to this effect must be declared.

learning_activities.topic:
Introduction & short history of anthropology

Welcome to anthropology! The first lecture will provide a short history of the discipline of anthropology and raise a series of key questions that the course seeks to address. We will also go over the course content, assessment and other details of what to expect.

Prepare for the lecture by reading over all the course materials and then read the first chapter of the textbook, Eller (2015) chapter 1, as well as the article by Proctor (2022). What are your questions about anthropology? Write a list of all the things you want to know and ask the best ones during class.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Human Diversity & ways to think it

Anthropology is unendingly interested in human societies, culture and all the diverse ways in which humans express ourselves as social (and sometimes anti-social!) beings, each one unique and with so many things in common. Enter the world of contradiction - how are humans one species and yet so diverse? What are the implications of this diversity and some of the history of understanding it?

To prepare for the lecture, read the textbook, Eller Chapter 2, and the article by Graeber & Wengrow (2021). You might have additional time to consider the recommended reading (a chapter of a book by Anne Salmond).

TUTORIAL: To prepare, write a short summary in your own words of the article by Graeber & Wengrow (2021). This is not assessed, but it will be useful for participating in the tutorial. In class, we will discuss how (and why) you should learn to write a good article summary, but give it a go on your own before class.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Culture, change, and globalisation

In the lecture we will examine the concept of 'culture', consider the ways that anthropologists trace cultural continuities and changes and think about culture in the context of globalisation. Prepare for the lecture by reading Eller Chapter 3 and the article by Li & Manzano (2021). The recommended reading by Mintz (1986, chapter 1) is a classic on the history of sugar and globalisation.

TUTORIAL: Bring a copy of your notes and summary of reading material to the tutorial to help you participate in the topic discussion. A discussion question will be raised in the lecture (and available in the lecture notes) to help guide your questions in class.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Relations: Kinship, the body and society

In the lecture we will examine how anthropologists consider 'relations' and what we mean by the term 'kinship'. Students will learn the basics of 'mapping' kinship and consider how our human bodies are formed as social and cultural processes. Prepare for the lecture by reading Eller Chapter 4 and the article by Jiang (2024). The recommended reading by Janice Boddy (2016) deals with (for some) confronting aspects of culturally legitimated body modification - **Trigger warning** please read with caution!

TUTORIAL: Bring a copy of your notes and summary of reading material to the tutorial to help you participate in the topic discussion. A discussion question will be raised in the lecture (and available in the lecture notes).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Communication, translation & representation

How is culture social (not individual)? Culture and social meanings are shared through different forms of communication. How do we think across cultures, or translate from one to the other? What are the problems of speaking and writing about (representing) cultures, both our own and others? Prepare for the lecture by reading Eller Chapter 5 and the article by Blasi (2024). Consider watching the entire film "Arrival" and reading the recommended readings as well. Muehlmann (2008) makes an argument for the special place of swear-words ("groserias") in one Indigenous language (northern Mexico) - dive in!

TUTORIAL: Bring a copy of your notes and summary of reading material to the tutorial to help you participate in the topic discussion. A discussion question will be raised in the lecture (and available in the lecture notes).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Value and moralities: anthropological approaches to economics

In the lecture we will examine how anthropologists consider economics to be cultural and social practice, revealing of value, values and moralities. We examine the history of money, the social processes in value creation and different experiences and meanings attributed to labour. Prepare for the lecture by reading Eller Chapter 6, and the book chapter by Graeber (2014), and perhaps also the article by Heuts & Mol (2013) on value.

TUTORIAL: Let's talk about economic value, other forms of value and moral life - bring your questions (based in the reading material) to class.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Doing and thinking ethnography : lecture instruction

The principle methodology of anthropology is ethnography, and it is sometimes also spoken of as a method, or a 'way of seeing'. How does ethnographic research work? In preparation for the lecture read the required readings, including the chapter from Eller (ch 9) and the Chapter by Lassiter (chapter 3). Consider reading chapter 7 of the book by Paige West on coffee. Bring your questions to the class.

Instructions for the Online Methods Workshops will be provided during the lecture.

TUTORIAL: Prepare for the Tutorial by reading the Eller chapter (9) and Lassiter (chapter 3) and begin online method workshops (Workshop one, notes, and upload to padlet.)

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Colonial politics & the state

This lecture opens up a discussion of the anthropology of politics. We will return to colonial and globalising dynamics, and give some background to what anthropologists might mean when we use the word 'politics'. Prepare for the lecture by reading Eller Chapter 7 and the article by Stead (2019) and recommended reading by Anderson (2003) or Kirsch (2009). How do anthropologists study politics and how is this different to other social scientists' approaches?

TUTORIAL: Bring your notes and questions on the topic discussion, from reading Eller, Chapter 7 and Stead. Do the Online Method Workshop 2 on Kinship.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

learning_activities.topic:
Ritual, religion and the symbolic

What IS religion? What does ritual DO? The lecture will consider a range of questions that anthropologists of religion and ritual have asked in order to contribute to understandings of human diversity. Prepare for the lecture by reading Eller Chapter 8 and the book chapter by Bielo (2015) and bring your notes to class. Consider the required readings as well.

NO Face to Face TUTORIAL. Do online method workshop 3, and upload your results of your observation to the padlet.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Ecology, energy, and connections

How do environmental anthropologists contribute to useful thinking on ecological problems? What are the connections that make ecological worlds social and cultural? How do new questions about energy matter to anthropologists? FILM "The Anthropologist" introduces some ways to think about environments and ethnographic work. Prepare for the lecture by reading the article by Begert (2021) and the chapter by Halvksz (2021). Consider the recommended reading by Henning (2005).

TUTORIAL: Bring your notes and questions on the topic discussion, informed by required & recommended reading.

Do the Online Methods Workshop 4 on Interviewing.

Where do we apply anthropology? Examples from 'Development', Design and Health applications
